measured_by: single-item 10-point self-report scale of willingness to take financial risk
justification: “Financial risk tolerance is a self-report on a 10-point scale… Participants are asked to rate the statement, ‘What is or has been over your lifetime your willingness to take risks in financial matters?’ on a scale from 1 to 10.”

measured_by: 10-item mixed-gamble choice task yielding a gamma coefficient
justification: “Risk aversion is assessed with 10 questions that ask participants if they would hypothetically prefer $15 for sure OR a coin toss… The risk aversion coefficient, gamma, is estimated based on the participant’s odds of choosing the gamble.”

“Temporal discounting is assessed with 10 questions that ask participants if they would prefer a smaller monetary reward now or a larger reward later… The hyperbolic time discount rate, alpha, is estimated…”

measured_by: 23-item financial knowledge and numeracy questionnaire (percentage correct)
justification: “Financial literacy is assessed with 23 questions designed to measure knowledge of financial information and concepts and numeracy… The score is the total percentage correct.”

measured_by: average of nine 4-point confidence ratings given after each knowledge question
justification: “Confidence in financial knowledge is based on the average of 9 questions… participants are asked, ‘How confident are you that you answered that question correctly?’ on a 4-point rating scale (1 = Not at all confident … 4 = Extremely confident).”

measured_by: 5-item self-report scale adapted from AARP and FINRA Risk Meter (7-point Likert)
justification: “Scam susceptibility is measured using a self-report scale based on content from AARP and questions from the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority's Risk Meter. Participants are asked to rate their agreement with 5 statements… using 7-point Likert scales.”

measured_by: single yes/no question about being a victim of financial fraud in past year
justification: “Fraud victimhood is a dichotomous variable for which participants respond to the question, ‘In the past year, were you a victim of financial fraud…?’ with Yes or No.”

measured_by: composite z-score averaged across 19 cognitive tests
justification: “A measure of global cognitive function is computed from an average of z-standardized scores from a battery of 19 cognitive tests that include measures of episodic memory, semantic memory, working memory, perceptual orientation, and perceptual speed.”

measured_by: difference score: z-scored confidence minus z-scored financial literacy
justification: “Overconfidence is z-scored confidence minus z-scored literacy based on whole sample means and standard deviations.”
